title: PM urged to act over ‘modern slavery’ in Amazon warehouses uncovered by Mirror
text:

Labour is demanding Boris Johnson takes action against Amazon after a Mirror probe into working conditions at the firm’s biggest UK warehouse.

Deputy leader Tom Watson has written a letter to the PM insisting the Mirror findings should be recognised because Amazon is in receipt of “significant government contracts”.

He said no further contracts should be handed to the tech giant until working conditions have improved.

We revealed a string of workers’ claims including pregnant women being told off for packing too slowly, exhausted staff sleeping in toilets and a union being clamped down upon by managers at the depot in Tilbury, Essex.

(Image: Getty)

We revealed a string of workers’ claims including pregnant women being told off for packing too slowly, exhausted staff sleeping in toilets and a union being clamped down upon by managers at the depot in Tilbury, Essex

Watson, the shadow secretary for digital, culture, media and sport, will also send the letter to his opposite number Nicky Morgan.

It states: “I write following the appalling revelations about working conditions at Amazon’s warehouse in Tillbury, Essex.

“The report by the Daily Mirror uncovered shocking treatment of workers who suffered from exhaustion after excessively long shifts with limited breaks.

(Image: PA)

“The staff recounted incidents where illness or injury was either ignored or not treated properly, in one instance with a taxi being called rather than an ambulance. Other staff say they are constantly surveilled by managers, with every minute of their time accounted for, including noting how long they spend in the toilet.

“Reading the Daily Mirror’s account of the working conditions at the factory, the staff description of it as ‘modern slavery’ does not seem inaccurate.

“As well as being generally concerning, these revelations should be of note to the Government because Amazon is currently in receipt of significant Government contracts.”

Amazon has won £500 million of Government contracts since 2015 and one third of government data is said to be stored on Amazon cloud services.

The government’s cloud service contracts are said to have grown by more than 50% in the last year.

(Image: Getty)

Watson said the “monopolistic” hold Amazon has on cloud services in the UK and across the world is “very concerning”.

He said it was another reason for competition authorities to scrutinise tech giants and for regulation to be introduced as soon as possible.

He wrote: “As I have argued previously, our failure to regulate the tech giants and introduce robust competition measures directly impacts on the nature of work and working conditions for millions of people.

“In the immediate term however, the Government must ensure that the abysmal working conditions detailed in the Daily Mirror article are not affecting any amazon workers servicing Government contracts, and the Government should not award any further contracts to any of Amazon’s business arms until working conditions have improved.

“I look forward to your response detailing how the Government is inspecting working conditions and confirming that no further contracts will be awarded to Amazon until conditions in their UK sites have improved.”
description: The move comes after a Mirror investigation into working conditions at the Amazon facility in Tilbury, Essex
